reviewText: We'll, once again, small budget and inept acting has kept an otherwise brilliant tale of Lovecraft's from being appreciated.Philip K. Dick has been explored as have the other SCI FI greats  HG WELLS, JULES VERNE, and ROBERT LOUIS STEVENSON. Now it is time for HP LOVECRAFT.QUIT packaging garbage and calling it LOVECRAFT! With a edgy exception of 3 medium budget films  "DAGON" ( The Shadow over Innsmouth), "The Resurrected" with Chris Sarandon, ( The Case of Charles Dexter Ward), and "Bleeders" with Rutger Hauer ( The Lurking Fear), all attempts at HP LOVECRAFT story telling have failed Miserably. DO NOT buy this, you WILL be disappointed.We now must all wait for Guillermo Del Toro to pick up the torch again for "The Mountains of Madness"....
Title: N/A

reviewText: I too made the grave mistake of buying this DVD on the glowing reviews posted here.  I won't go so far as to say anyone was lying about this movie, but....Truly, by any definition, this was anything but a horror movie.  At 75 minutes too long, this was just an utter bore, pure conceit.  It was a complete waste of my time.  My initial response after having trudged my way through it: fury.  And!  I can't believe I shelled out that much money for this dreck.The biggest problem with this film is that it features not one but two artists painting the same thing.  It's a funny thing, but if you're going to deal with art as a fundamental aspect of a movie then you need to show the art in question, not just show poor actors responding in freakish ways because of the art they were allowed to see, but we weren't (for our own sanity?).  This became even more patently idiotic during a scene in which Pickman's landlady calls the police and wants him arrested for bad art!  Art that's never seen, I can't emphasize that enough because it's crucial to the plot!  The only thing we're shown are terrible sketches of a church steeple.  That's it.  Hardly cause for anyone going mad.I will say I managed to make it all the way through this monumental bore but it was a chore!  I wouldn't pass this along to my worst enemy.  But it's definitely not a keeper.
summary: Definitely not the stuff of nightmares!
Title: N/A

reviewText: This is probably the best "HP Lovecraft Inspired" DVD since In the Mouth of Maddness, but you will still roll your eyes at a few things.As other reviewers did, I gave this 5 stars, since the genre is sadly devoid of titles from people that actually read Lovecraft.  There are some great reviews already, which compelled me to watch this, so I'll hit on what they missed: what went wrong.Mostly, it was bad writing that caused issues in the film, but bad acting accented the problem in places:1) The landlady/her family (no spoilers)The landlady was an appropriate racial stereotype, but written in sore, afterthought 2D . . . the actresses carried this through, and brought nothing redeeming to the roles, missing an opportune chance to win a following in a cult genre.  Not entirely their fault, but it *was* something they could have fixed themselves.2) The ENTIRE asylum staff/institution (not really spoilers, since this is HPL, you kind of expect this):This was totally wrong and unresearched; one could go to a modern hospital and realize that early-1900's sanatorium and find better security and less inept doctors/staff, but this movies is set in the modern-era, so it's totally inexcusable.3) Who hired the lead doctor?There is a special place in 'actor's hell' for Maurice McNicholas . . . I really can't say more.  Think: Junior High School Play - a-la William Shatner caricature . . .Okay, I honestly feel bad for saying so, since (again) it's a lacking genre and it was a good movie, so . . . I'll add the highpoints:1) Recurring names . . . it's littered with great names here and there, and that's part of what makes 'mythos' mythos . . .2) It's Lovecraftian (captial L there) . . . it's horrific and disturbing . . . but modern horror fans will neither get it or find it scary (It's NR,but I'd call it PG-13, maybe even PG)3) Barret Walz did a fabulous job -- I'd be surprised if he wasn't a Lovecraft fan ----- if not, he's a SUPERB actor4) It's well written, overall . . . as I mentioned, best since ItMoM.

reviewText: Follows Pickman's Model accurately, minimal gore and more of an overwhelming, ever-present sense of menace. Just as it should be with any of HP Lovecraft's works.

reviewText: I liked the film and would recommend it for any Lovecraft fan. I feel this is one of the "better" attempts at a Lovecraft film. It has some very dark atmospheres and a doomed feel throughout the whole film. If you are a fan I say give it a try.

reviewText: I bought this movie because I love the stories of H.P. Lovecraft, but this was just not my kind of movie.  I only watched it once, several months ago, then donated it to our public library, so I can't really go into details about what I didn't like, and what someone else might like.  A movie, based on Lovecraft, that I CAN recommend, is The Whisperer In Darkness.  Sorry if I disappoint anyone, but honesty is best.
summary: JUST NOT A MOVIE FOR ME

reviewText: The acting is on an amateur level with the exception of the Pickman character.  The best and most honest thing to do is to film an author's work as it was written and not pretend to improve on it.  Failure to follow the intellectual copyright holder's script is a confession of envy.
summary: the angles aren't as wrong as the acting

reviewText: This film is a short, but is well made and true to the Lovecraft mythos. It is made in a style that evokes the way Lovecraft wrote and is the kind of tale of no happy ending that Lovecraft wrote so well. I highly recommend it.
summary: This film is a short, but true to the Lovecraft story

reviewerName: Wilum Hopfrog Pugmire, Esq. "H. P. Lovecraft ...
reviewText: "The Haunter of the Dark" is one of my two all-time favourite tales by H. P. Lovecraft, and I was overwhelmed when I saw this magnificent cinematic adaptation on the big screen at last year's H. P. Lovecraft Film Festival.  The trailer may be seen at YouTube and there you can catch a glimpse of the power this film contains, especially the lead actor's brilliant performance and the interior/exterior shots of that haunted church!  I look forward to seeing this DVD, and I'm very proud that they used a quote of mine on the back of the DVD box.  As soon as I've watched the DVD I shall give a full review of it and the film here.  Highly recommended!UPDATE:  Yesterday's post brought me the DVD of this amazing film, and although I can watch DVDs only on the small screen of my laptop, I was sucked into this powerful Lovecraftian film completely; indeed, the film so gets under your skin that to watch it alone, in your basement, with your headphones on, is a potently CREEPY feeling!  The DVD is very attractive, and the only thing it lacks that I would have enjoyed is a behind-the-scenes segment shewing the making of the film and interviewing Robert Cappelletto, who is the poetic genius behind the production.  Not only did he direct the film and write its screenplay, he also served as the film's editor, and editing is such an amazingly important aspect, indeed that's where a film often comes completely to life, finds its rhythm, &c.;  There are no accidents in this film, there is nothing extraneous -- it is a perfect whole, from the opening image of ghastly red paint dripping from a brush to the image of water dripping from a rag around a ceiling pipe to the final awesome image of unearthly black water dripping from a shard of broken glass.  The other reviews have mentioned the power of Barret Walz's magnetic performance, which is realistic in every way.  He is stunning, but he does not carry the film alone.  Maurice McNicholas as Dr. Dexter gives a solid yet strange performance that is keeping with such Lovecraftian "old men" as Dr. Willet in "The Case of Charles Dexter Ward," Dr. Whipple in "The Shunned House," and Henry Armitage in "The Dunwich Horror."  He is the sane man who has had a brush with cosmic horror and the madness that such horror can spawn, who finds himself once more caught into a web of nameless menace.  As portrayed in this film, the Dr. is a rather ineffective adversary, yet the tragedy of his experience is revealed full-force with a performance that grows in tragic portrayal.  One of the strongest scenes in the brilliant screenplay is the meeting between Robert Pickman and Goodie Hines (played with splendid lunacy by Tom Lodewick) -- one can feel the fusion of these souls whose sanity has been melted by their encounter with cosmic nightmare.  The use of light and darkness in this film is brilliant.  But most important, for me as an obsessed Lovecraft fan, is that the film is absolutely successful in conjuring the power of Lovecraft's original story, all the while being the director's unique interpretation of that story.  One of the fine moments that caused me to gasp in eldritch Lovecraftian pleasure is the bit where a flock of birds are flying toward the Starry Wisdom steeple, only to suddenly divert its course and turn away from the haunted edifice.  This is straight out of Lovecraft:"He believed that a vague, singular aura of desolation hovered over the place, so that even pigeons and swallows shunned its smoky eaves.  Around other towers and belfries his glass would reveal great flocks of birds, but here they never rested."Also directly from Lovecraft is the spectral image of the church against the moving sky, as Lovecraft describes it, "...at sunset the great tower and tapering steeple loomed blackly against the flaming sky."  The colour of that flaming sky is caught to perfection in this film, in a shade of orange-yellow that becomes one of the recurring visual motifs.  This is contrasted, expertly, when the preternatural storm comes to the city, its black and tempest swirling around the steeple of Starry Wisdom, and then the daemon that issues from that steeple as a black cloud of sentient smoke.  PICKMAN'S MUSE is, all in all, a perfect cinematic portrayal of that which rocks my world, that fabulous creature that we call "Lovecraftian horror."  Ia!
